TITLE: Glass act: Scientists reveal secrets of frog transparency
SUMMARY: Using light and ultrasound imaging technology, researchers discovered the secret: While asleep, the frogs concentrate, or “hide,” nearly 90% of their red blood cells in their livers

TITLE: Alzheimer's researchers study genes in Puerto Rican and Latino families
SUMMARY: They have found that in Puerto Rico, people have a higher propensity for the disease, and part of the reason could be a genetic variant they have uncovered

TITLE: EPA issues new rule to strengthen water protections in the U.S.
SUMMARY: Under the new definition of "waters of the United States," more wetlands, lakes and rivers will qualify as federally protected

TITLE: The year in space: Why 2022 was a pivotal year for exploration and discovery
SUMMARY: This year brought space fans images from the world’s most powerful space telescope, the debut launch of NASA’s moon rocket and a test to redirect an asteroid

TITLE: What is the XBB.1.5 subvariant? CDC reports a new strain of omicron taking over in the U.S.
SUMMARY: About 40% of confirmed U.S. Covid cases are caused by the XBB.1.5 strain, up from 20% a week ago

TITLE: 2022 was the year of drought
SUMMARY: Lakes and rivers in several countries shrank to extreme lows, and dry conditions threatened crops and fueled destructive wildfires across the globe

TITLE: Atmospheric river expected to trigger 'bomb cyclone' and more flooding in California
SUMMARY: Flood watches were in effect for 12 million people in the northern part of the state, including areas still recovering from recent storms and mudslides

TITLE: Walter Cunningham, last surviving Apollo 7 astronaut, dies at 90
SUMMARY: Cunningham's family said he died "after a full and complete life." He was one of three astronauts aboard the 1968 Apollo 7 mission

TITLE: Mexico's Mayan Train critically threatens ancient, pristine areas, scientists warn
SUMMARY: The railway and its hasty construction will endanger wilderness and ancient cave systems beneath the jungle floor, say droves of environmental experts and scientists

TITLE: U.S. greenhouse emissions show signs of slowing — but not quickly enough
SUMMARY: The Rhodium Group's analysis suggests the U.S. is off track to reach fast-approaching climate goals in 2025 and 2030

TITLE: Extreme weather caused $165 billion in damage last year, NOAA says
SUMMARY: It was the third-costliest year on record, highlighting the enormous economic and societal toll of extreme events that are expected to intensify because of climate change

TITLE: U.K. space industry mulls setback after satellite launch fails
SUMMARY: U.S.-based Virgin Orbit attempted its first international launch late Monday, using a modified jumbo jet to carry one if its rockets from Cornwall, England, over the Atlantic

TITLE: James Webb Telescope finds its first exoplanet
SUMMARY: The planet is almost the same size as Earth, according to a research team led by astronomers at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory

TITLE: Surging rivers highlight a big dam problem for California
SUMMARY: Much of the infrastructure to help alleviate California’s too-wet/too-dry cycles — its extensive reservoir system — was designed long before it was recognized that climate change could intensify droughts and storms

TITLE: Exxon Mobil accurately predicted warming since 1970s, study finds
SUMMARY: The study in the journal Science looked at Exxon-funded research that used more than a dozen different computer models that forecast the coming warming with precision equal to or better that of than government and academic scientists

TITLE: NASA and NOAA find 2022 was one of the hottest years on record
SUMMARY: Though the two agencies differed slightly in their rankings, both analyses painted the same broad and alarming picture of persistent warming amid Earth’s changing climate

TITLE: More men diagnosed with advanced prostate cancer as PSA screening declines
SUMMARY: After two decades of decline, cases of prostate cancer rose by 3% per year from 2014 to 2019, a new report from the American Cancer Society has found

TITLE: Norway archaeologists find 'world's oldest runestone'
SUMMARY: The flat, square block of brownish sandstone has carved scribbles, which may be the earliest example of words recorded in writing in Scandinavia

TITLE: Twinkle, twinkle fading stars: Hiding in our brighter skies
SUMMARY: A new study that analyzes data from more than 50,000 amateur stargazers finds that artificial lighting is making the night sky about 10% brighter every year

TITLE: The Great Salt Lake is at risk of ecological collapse. Lawmakers are scrambling to buy more time.
SUMMARY: The shrinking Great Salt Lake is facing ecological collapse as salinity levels rise. State leaders hope a hearty snowpack and a surplus in the state budget can save the lake — or at least buy them time

TITLE: Scientists set Doomsday Clock closer to midnight than ever before
SUMMARY: The Bulletin of Atomic Scientists warned that humanity is facing a time of “unprecedented danger

TITLE: Scans reveal secrets of Egypt's mummified 'golden boy,' buried for 2,300 years
SUMMARY: Radiologists at Cairo University in Egypt used CT scans to "digitally unwrap" the remains, uncovering signs of wealth as well as efforts to ensure his safe passage to the afterlife

TITLE: SpaceX completes Starship test in prep for rocket’s first orbital launch attempt
SUMMARY: Starship is a nearly 400-foot-tall rocket designed to carry cargo and people beyond Earth

TITLE: Tornado Alley is creeping into new territory
SUMMARY: In recent years, researchers have noticed that fewer tornadoes were touching down in the Great Plains and that more were hitting the Southeast

TITLE: Asteroid coming exceedingly close to Earth but will miss
SUMMARY: Even if the space rock came a lot closer, scientists said, most of it would burn up in the atmosphere, with some of the bigger pieces possibly falling as meteorites

TITLE: Fossilized eggs reveal new secrets about one of the world's largest dinosaurs
SUMMARY: The find “offers new insights into the conditions of nest preservation and reproductive strategies of titanosaur sauropod dinosaurs,” said Harsha Dhiman, the study’s lead author

TITLE: Amid high levels of contamination, Puerto Rico town's residents plead for action
SUMMARY: For years, toxic ash and noxious chemicals have enveloped Salinas, and the EPA recently announced it had found extremely high concentrations of a carcinogenic gas

TITLE: Bigger, faster, farther: A batch of new rockets is set to blast into space this year
SUMMARY: From new boosters to replacing old workhorses to the first flight of a rocket billed as the tallest and most powerful ever built, here’s what is on the horizon

TITLE: Aftershocks as strong as Turkey's 2nd quake are rare, experts say
SUMMARY: Typically, aftershocks are a full magnitude unit lower than the initial quake, according to seismologists. Not this time

TITLE: The U.S. has a long history of environmental protests. Police had never killed an activist — until now.
SUMMARY: Police have often been important intermediaries in environmental protests. In a forest outside Atlanta, they were opponents

TITLE: Carnivores' attacks on humans are becoming more common, and climate change isn't helping
SUMMARY: Rising population has led to increased human encroachment on natural habitats, but climate change is also pushing some animals closer to population centers, experts say

TITLE: Beyond magnitude: A shallow earthquake hammered Turkey
SUMMARY: Earthquakes can originate at various depths beneath the Earth’s surface — even hundreds of miles deep — but shallower earthquakes can be more destructive.&nbsp

TITLE: The fate of America's largest supply of helium is up in the air
SUMMARY: The Federal Helium Reserve was supposed to be sold off in 2021. Scientists hope it will remain in government hands

TITLE: Nevada lithium mine wins ruling; green energy fights rage on
SUMMARY: It’s the latest development in a series battles that pit environmentalists and others against projects meant to speed the nation’s transition from fossil fuels to renewable energy

TITLE: Team USA skiers sport climate change-inspired race suits in France
SUMMARY: The blue-and-white pattern on the suits is based off a satellite photo of melting ice caps

TITLE: Coming to a campus near you: Nuclear microreactors
SUMMARY: Small but meaningful amounts of electricity can pulse from a new generation of micronuclear reactors. Universities are taking interest

TITLE: Seeking motivated voters, an environment-focused nonprofit turns to red states
SUMMARY: The Environmental Voter Project said they see an opportunity to bridge the partisan gap, noting that many Republican-led states are home to some of the worst climate-fueled impacts — and potentially the most significant opportunities for reform

TITLE: As bird flu spreads to minks, sea lions and other mammals, scientists are on alert for dangerous mutations
SUMMARY: Adapted to birds, H5N1 has been found in various mammals, but it would need a complicated string of mutations to spread more easily in people

TITLE: SpaceX ignites giant Starship rocket in crucial pad test
SUMMARY: Elon Musk estimates Starship’s first orbital test flight could occur as soon as March, if the test analyses and remaining preparations go well

TITLE: Russia delays launch to space station while leak is probed
SUMMARY: The leak was detected after a second supply ship docked with the space station

TITLE: Possibility that unidentified flying objects were weather balloons deepens the mystery
SUMMARY: The National Weather Service confirmed that none of the objects shot down in recent days belonged to the agency. And science balloons are usually well-tracked, an industry leader said

TITLE: Scientists take a peek below Antarctica's 'doomsday glacier'
SUMMARY: Using an underwater drone, researchers were able to study cracks and crevasses in the Thwaites Eastern Ice Shelf and take key measurements where the ice meets the ocean

TITLE: Record-breaking footprint found on England's 'Dinosaur Coast'
SUMMARY: More than 3 feet long, the footprint was made by a meat-eating theropod dinosaur almost 166 million years ago from the Jurassic Period

TITLE: Powerful radars, limited scope: How no one spotted a bunch of 'objects' floating in NORAD airspace
SUMMARY: Weather scientists, government agencies and the military all have powerful radar systems to detect objects at a very granular level — but they filter their view depending on their mission

TITLE: Hurricanes could push deeper into U.S. in coming decades
SUMMARY: A new projection found more intense storms triggered by climate change will expose millions more properties to wind damage in the next 30 years

TITLE: Last-minute problem grounds SpaceX rocket and astronauts
SUMMARY: The countdown was halted with just two minutes to go. With just a split second to blast off, there was no time to deal with the problem, which involved the engine ignition system

TITLE: The moon could get its own time zone. But clocks won't work the same as they do on Earth.
SUMMARY: The European Space Agency said Monday that there is a need to establish some synchronicity in how we tell time on the Moon as many countries race to explore it

TITLE: CDC warns about the rise in almost untreatable Shigella bacterial infections
SUMMARY: The drug-resistant stomach bug, a major cause of inflammatory diarrhea, is a "serious public health threat

TITLE: Ancient restaurant highlights Iraq’s archaeology renaissance
SUMMARY: The discovery came against the backdrop of a resurgence of archaeology in a country often referred to as the "cradle of civilization

TITLE: With its energy grid under fire, some in Ukraine turn to small-scale renewables
SUMMARY: As Russia’s assault continues, several nonprofit groups in Ukraine are working to fill energy gaps — caused either by attacks on the energy grid or broader energy shortages — with renewable infrastructure

TITLE: SpaceX launches U.S., Russia and UAE astronauts to space station
SUMMARY: The Falcon rocket bolted from Kennedy Space Center shortly after midnight, illuminating the night sky as it headed up the East Coast

TITLE: Tribes bury Southern California’s famed mountain lion, P-22
SUMMARY: After making his home near the Hollywood Sign for the past decade, P-22 became a symbol for California’s endangered mountain lions and their decreasing genetic diversity

TITLE: Inside the fierce debate over clean hydrogen, with $100 billion in federal subsidies on the line
SUMMARY: The impact of the tax credit on emissions reductions depends on how federal agencies implement it. And, as with most things in accounting, the devil is in the details

TITLE: Space startup forced to call off launch of world's first 3D-printed rocket
SUMMARY: It's not yet known what issues were encountered at the launchpad, but company officials said a new launch date and time will be announced soon

TITLE: Japan's new rocket fails on debut flight, in blow to space ambitions
SUMMARY: Upon reaching space, the H3 rocket’s second-stage engine failed to ignite, forcing mission officials to manually destroy the vehicle

TITLE: Viking treasure reveals oldest reference to Norse god Odin
SUMMARY: Before the Vindelev hoard’s discovery, the oldest mention of Odin was a brooch found in southern Germany from the latter half of the 6th century

TITLE: Dutch historian discovers medieval treasure using metal detector
SUMMARY: A Dutch historian found a unique 1,000-year-old medieval golden treasure, consisting of four golden ear pendants, two strips of gold leaf and 39 silver coins

TITLE: A giant seaweed bloom that can be seen from space threatens beaches in Florida and Mexico
SUMMARY: Seasonal sargassum blooms have exploded in the tropical Atlantic over the past decade and more. This year's is already staggeringly large

TITLE: Last-minute aborts thwart launch of world's first 3D-printed rocket
SUMMARY: “Based on initial data review, vehicle is healthy. More info to follow on cause of aborts today,” the company said in an update on Twitter

TITLE: Utah is flush with snow and money. It might not be enough to save the Great Salt Lake.
SUMMARY: Intense snowfall will lead to extra water this spring, and $400 million from the state government will help ongoing concerns. Some still worry Utah is wasting a blessing.&nbsp

TITLE: Major climate report issues a dire outlook for human life on Earth
SUMMARY: The U.N.'s IPCC report is the culmination of more than six years of work by thousands of climate scientists

TITLE: Candidates who support psychedelics as medicine get a political action committee
SUMMARY: Psychedelic Medicine PAC will focus on securing federal funding for more research on how magic mushrooms, ketamine and similar substances can treat various disorders

TITLE: Koalas may be extinct in Australia's New South Wales by 2050
SUMMARY: Land clearing for agriculture, urban development, mining and forestry had been the biggest factor in the fragmentation and loss of habitat for the animals

TITLE: Deadly earthquake in Ecuador brings grief and fear
SUMMARY: Ecuador is particularly vulnerable to earthquakes. The quake killed at least 15 people and injured more than 445 others

TITLE: Deadly fungal infection spreading at an alarming rate, CDC says
SUMMARY: The fungus, a type of yeast called Candida auris, or C. auris, can cause severe illness in people with weakened immune systems

TITLE: Super-size trapdoor spider discovered in Australia
SUMMARY: The arachnid has been named Euoplos dignitas to reflect "the impressive size and nature of the spider," scientists with the Queensland Museum said

TITLE: DNA from Beethoven's hair offers clues about what made him sick
SUMMARY: Researchers weren’t able to crack the case of the German composer’s deafness or severe stomach ailments, but they did find other factors that could've affected his health

TITLE: World's first 3D-printed rocket launches but fails to reach orbit in key test flight
SUMMARY: The booster experienced an anomaly with its upper stage several minutes into its inaugural mission

TITLE: What's to fear about warming oceans? Flesh-eating bacteria
SUMMARY: While Vibrio vulnificus infections are still rare, the findings provide further evidence of how human health and the health of the planet are inextricably linked

TITLE: ‘City killer’ asteroid will pass between Earth and the moon’s orbit
SUMMARY: “There is no chance of this ‘city killer’ striking Earth, but its close approach offers a great opportunity for observations,” the European Space Agency’s planetary defense chief Richard Moissl said in a statement

TITLE: Wind industry predicts bounceback and rapid growth in 2023
SUMMARY: This year, the industry will reach a milestone — 1 terawatt, or 1,000 gigawatts, of wind energy installed worldwide, says the Global Wind Energy Council

TITLE: Public pensions get caught up in Republican push to end 'woke' investing
SUMMARY: Business groups, labor unions and others are sounding off against state GOP efforts to bar public pensions from making environmentally and socially conscious investments

TITLE: Lethal supercell storms to hit South more often as world warms, new study says
SUMMARY: While the study finds a general increase in supercell counts, what it mostly finds are large shifts in where and when they hit — generally, more east of Interstate 35, which runs through east central Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas, and fewer to the west

TITLE: EPA pressured for transparency around dioxin testing after Ohio derailment
SUMMARY: The EPA said levels of the cancer-causing chemicals are “similar to typical background levels,” but have not yet released any data

TITLE: Planets on parade: Five line up in night sky tonight
SUMMARY: The five-planet spread — of Mercury, Jupiter, Venus, Uranus and Mars — can be seen from anywhere on Earth, as long as you have clear skies and a view of the west

TITLE: As superbug infections grow more common, the world is running out of drugs to treat them
SUMMARY: Health officials are sounding increasingly urgent alarms about the need for powerful new drugs to treat increasingly resistant infections

TITLE: At a climate conference for conservatives, urgency for action meets caution on messaging
SUMMARY: “At the time, it was both safe and popular for Republicans to deny climate change,” one speaker said of previous generations of politicians. “But times are changing

TITLE: Virgin Orbit fails to secure funding and will cease operations
SUMMARY: Virgin Orbit stock closed at 34 cents a share Thursday, having fallen 82% since the beginning of the year

TITLE: A long-dormant lake has reappeared in California, bringing havoc along with it
SUMMARY: Months of atmospheric river storms have pummeled the area, which is home to crucial farmland. A historic snowpack in the mountains above the basin will make things worse

TITLE: Meet the 'world's deepest fish,' filmed for the first time at bone-crushing depths
SUMMARY: Researchers using an autonomous deep-ocean vessel recorded the unknown snailfish species at a bone-crushing depth of 27,349 feet

TITLE: Why the U.S. leads the world in weather catastrophes
SUMMARY: Blame geography for the U.S.'s getting hit by stronger, costlier, more varied and frequent extreme weather. Then add climate change, and "buckle up

TITLE: Sleep apnea linked to cognitive problems even in otherwise healthy men, new research shows
SUMMARY: Middle-age men with obstructive sleep apnea showed poorer mental function in areas such as judgment and impulse control, new research finds

TITLE: 478 tornado reports across 25 states: How a mild winter led to destruction
SUMMARY: A picture is emerging of how tornado risks are changing across parts of the country, particularly in areas where social factors compound vulnerabilities to extreme weather

TITLE: Climate change is leading to more home runs, study finds
SUMMARY: Warmer temperatures helped at least 500 more long balls sail over MLB fences from 2010 to 2019, according to a study from Dartmouth College researchers

TITLE: Scientists find world's deepest fish
SUMMARY: Scientists caught an unknown snailfish species at a depth of more than five miles underwater in Japan, a new record for the deepest fish ever filmed. Wildlife expert Forrest Galante speaks with NBC’s Gadi Schwartz about the discovery.&nbsp

TITLE: High risk, high reward: Startups are still eager to mine space rocks
SUMMARY: With a more robust commercial space economy and launch lower costs now, deep-space mining startups are poised to pick up where others have failed

TITLE: T. rex skeleton sells for more than $5M at Zurich auction
SUMMARY: Promoters said the composite T. rex, dubbed “Trinity,” was built from specimens retrieved from three sites in the Hell Creek and Lance Creek formations of Montana and Wyoming from 2008 to 2013

TITLE: India's heat is underestimated and harming its progress, study says
SUMMARY: Extreme heat puts 80% of India’s 1.4 billion population in danger, the study found

TITLE: How A.I. is changing the film industry
SUMMARY: Artificial intelligence has recently been tested in the film industry and is beginning to make waves as the future of filmmaking. Director and storyteller Jon Finger created his short, D.A.N., by utilizing mostly A.I. generated images and video.&nbsp

TITLE: Aliens? Falling satellite? Unexplained flash puzzles Kyiv accustomed to Russian missiles
SUMMARY: Residents, including top officials, seemed to enjoy speculating that the flash could be unrelated to the war

TITLE: 'Awesome' solar eclipse wows viewers in Australia, Indonesia
SUMMARY: The remote tourist town of Exmouth, with fewer than 3,000 residents, was promoted as one of the best vantage points in Australia to see the eclipse

TITLE: The seat belt sign is on: Viral videos and climate change boost concerns about turbulence
SUMMARY: Scientists have warned that climate change could cause more severe turbulence over the coming decades, and some studies have already observed an increase in such disruptions

TITLE: Climate change is causing more 'heat stress' in Europe
SUMMARY: The European Commission’s Copernicus Climate Change Service said comparisons of data going back over decades showed record heat last year resulted in hazardous conditions for human health

TITLE: SpaceX's giant rocket blasts off on first test flight — and explodes minutes later
SUMMARY: The rocket — the most powerful ever developed — is set to play a key role in NASA’s Artemis program, which plans to put humans on the moon in 2025

TITLE: 'Devastating' melt of Greenland, Antarctic ice sheets found
SUMMARY: Using 50 satellite estimates, researchers found that Greenland’s melt has gone into hyperdrive in the last few years

TITLE: California researchers attempt ocean climate solution
SUMMARY: The technology, dubbed SeaChange, developed by the University of California Los Angeles engineering faculty, is meant to seize on the ocean’s ability to take in carbon dioxide

TITLE: Is hydrogen the clean fuel of the future?
SUMMARY: Researchers are looking into how water or hydrogen could be turned into a source of fuel that does not produce any carbon emissions. NBC’s Jake Ward has more.&nbsp

TITLE: Here's where extreme heat could be devastating in coming years
SUMMARY: A new study found that heat waves intensified by climate change, combined with existing socioeconomic issues, will create potentially devastating vulnerabilities

TITLE: SpaceX Starship explosion spread particulate matter for miles
SUMMARY: The Federal Aviation Administration grounded the company’s Starship Super Heavy launch program pending results of a "mishap investigation

TITLE: Japanese company says moon lander unexpectedly accelerated and likely crashed
SUMMARY: If all had gone well, ispace would have been the first private business to pull off a lunar landing

TITLE: A 'pollen storm' is causing many adults to suffer from allergies for the first time
SUMMARY: A "pollen storm" and longer allergy seasons are sending a growing number of adults in search of relief

TITLE: Doctors increasingly prescribing amphetamines along with antidepressants, researcher warns
SUMMARY: Drugs like Ritalin are being given off-label to counteract the side effects of psychiatric prescriptions, a study suggests

TITLE: Engineers develop water filtration system that permanently removes 'forever chemicals'
SUMMARY: Engineers at the University of British Columbia have developed a filtration system that would permanently remove "forever chemicals" from drinking water. This news comes after a recent study revealed nearly 200 million Americans have been exposed to PFAS in their tap water. Dr. Madjid Mohseni, a professor at British Columbia, shares his research.&nbsp

TITLE: FAA sued over SpaceX Starship launch program after April explosion
SUMMARY: Five environmental and cultural heritage groups are suing the Federal Aviation Administration over its dealings with SpaceX

TITLE: Manchin introduces bill to speed energy permitting
SUMMARY: Some clean energy advocates have said the legislation is key to implementing an energy transition supported by last year’s Inflation Reduction Act, which had $369 billion in tax breaks and other incentives to help combat climate change

TITLE: In a galactic first, a star is seen swallowing a planet in one gulp
SUMMARY: It’s a gloomy preview of what will happen to Earth when our sun morphs into a red giant and gobbles the four inner planets

TITLE: Dust storms have killed hundreds and are a growing problem in parts of the U.S.
SUMMARY: Fast-moving winds can suddenly whip dirt and debris into the air, leading to fatal accidents. It's an issue worsened by drought, climate change and land management

TITLE: Deadly combo of extreme heat and air pollution grips parts of Southeast Asia
SUMMARY: As greenhouse gas emissions degrade air quality around the world and global warming makes heat waves both more frequent and more severe, the combined risks could set off a public health crisis

TITLE: Scientists announce rough draft of human pangenome
SUMMARY: A collection of DNA that represents the genetic information from 47 individuals, the pangenome dramatically expands upon the original human genome reference

TITLE: Babies who have DNA from three different people born in the U.K. for first time
SUMMARY: In 2015, the U.K. became the first country to adopt legislation regulating methods to help prevent women with faulty mitochondria from passing defects on to their babies

TITLE: 'No Mow May' encourages homeowners to help bees by letting their lawns grow
SUMMARY: Dozens of communities across the U.S. have adopted "No Mow May" and are letting bee-friendly plants grow in their yards

TITLE: Meteorite crashes through roof of New Jersey home and bounces around in a bedroom
SUMMARY: Scientists with The College of New Jersey determined the 6-by-4-inch object, which weighs about 2.2 pounds, is a rare stony chondrite meteorite

TITLE: Black astronaut says lunar mission will be 'major accomplishment' in American history
SUMMARY: Victor Glover is part of a four-member crew that will orbit the moon in NASA’s Artemis II mission, scheduled for November 2024

TITLE: In the Amazon, Brazilian ecologists try new approach against deforestation and poverty
SUMMARY: The goal is ambitious — counter the forces that have destroyed 10% of the forest in less than four decades and create something that can be replicated in other parts of the Amazon

TITLE: Extreme weather has killed 2 million people over past half century, U.N. says
SUMMARY: The World Meteorological Organization tallied nearly 12,000 extreme weather, climate and water-related events over the past half-century that caused economic damage of $4.3 trillion

TITLE: Three states agree to reduce water usage so the Colorado River doesn't go dry
SUMMARY: A new plan would conserve at least 3 million acre-feet of water by 2026 in an effort to ensure the crucial waterway continues to generate power and provide drinking water

TITLE: NASA has sights set on Mars with help from a nuclear rocket engine
SUMMARY: A conventional spacecraft powered by burning liquid fuel typically takes around seven or eight months to reach the red planet. Scientists have said nuclear rocket engines could shave off at least a third of that time

TITLE: San Francisco's Coit Tower, Twitter HQ and thousands of other buildings may be at risk of a severe quake
SUMMARY: A draft list of San Francisco concrete buildings reveals properties that the city says could be vulnerable to earthquakes and may need costly upgrades

TITLE: Scientists are puzzled by Orcas sinking boats in a string of abnormal attacks
SUMMARY: A string of incidents since 2020 prompted one scientist to say the attacks may indicate that the whales are intending to cause damage to sailing vessels. Others are more skeptical

TITLE: Multivitamins may help slow loss of memory as people get older
SUMMARY: Those who took a daily Centrum Silver pill over a period of three years had better memories than those who received a placebo treatment, new research found

TITLE: Military must focus on short- and long-term challenges of climate change, report finds
SUMMARY: A Rand Corp. study maps out the various ways climate change will impact the military's personnel, equipment, facilities, supply chain and ability to engage with allies and partners

TITLE: Ron DeSantis signs Florida bill limiting the liabilities of private spaceflight companies
SUMMARY: DeSantis signed the bill a day after he launched his campaign for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination in an event with Twitter’s owner Elon Musk, who is also the CEO of SpaceX

TITLE: NOAA predicts 'near-normal' hurricane season
SUMMARY: NOAA forecasters are predicting a 40% chance of a near-normal hurricane season, including one to four “major” hurricanes that reach Category 3 or higher with winds of at least 111 mph

TITLE: China plans to land astronauts on moon before 2030, expand space station, bring on foreign partners
SUMMARY: China and the U.S. are rivals in a race to reach new milestones in outer space

TITLE: Memorial Day 'Manhattanhenge' to light up New York City streets
SUMMARY: This year’s Manhattanhenge dates correspond with both Memorial Day and Major League Baseball’s All-Star break

TITLE: NASA panel studying UFO sightings says stigma and poor data pose challenges
SUMMARY: The 16-member panel, which formed last year, presented early findings Wednesday in its first public meeting. A final report is expected this summer

TITLE: World’s wheat supply at risk of a dangerous shock due to heat and drought, study warns
SUMMARY: New research outlines a worst-case scenario in which extreme weather hammers winter wheat crops in both the U.S. Midwest and northeastern China in the same year

TITLE: Arizona limits new housing around Phoenix because of dwindling water supply
SUMMARY: Officials said developers could still build in the affected areas but would need to find alternative water sources to do so — such as surface or recycled water

TITLE: Two California lakes are making comebacks with different results
SUMMARY: The return of Owens Lake threatens billions of dollars in efforts to stem air pollution, while the resurgent Mono Lake is generating cautious optimism

TITLE: Here comes El Niño: It's early, likely to be big, sloppy and add even more heat to a warming world
SUMMARY: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Thursday issued an El Niño advisory, announcing the arrival of the climatic condition. It may not quite be like the others

TITLE: 125 degrees? Puerto Rico faces 'dangerous situation' due to record-breaking heat
SUMMARY: “It’s not just climate, and it’s not just weather. It’s a combination of the two that’s leading to what, frankly, is a dangerous situation,” said meteorologist John Morales

TITLE: Experimental drug for marijuana addiction shows promise, small study finds
SUMMARY: There's no FDA-approved medication to treat cannabis use disorder, which may affect millions of Americans

TITLE: Taurine, a nutrient found in high-protein foods, slows aging in animals — and maybe humans, too
SUMMARY: Scientists report that increasing the nutrient found in protein-rich foods may slow the aging process, leading to longer, healthier lives in animals — and maybe humans, too

TITLE: How New York's day of smoke laid bare the realities of climate catastrophe
SUMMARY: Wildfire smoke experts said that it would have been difficult to foresee such dramatic impacts but that climate change is also reshaping natural hazards at a startling pace

TITLE: Yes, flesh-eating bacteria can hitch rides on seaweed and plastic (no, don't cancel your summer vacation)
SUMMARY: A recent study stoked fears of flesh-eating bacteria invading beaches across Florida, the Caribbean and elsewhere in the Gulf of Mexico. Experts aren't worried ... yet

TITLE: Youth environmentalists bring Montana climate case to trial after 12 years, seeking to set precedent
SUMMARY: It’s the first trial of its kind in the U.S., and legal scholars around the world are following its potential addition to the small number of rulings that have established a government duty to protect people from climate change

TITLE: Chemical traces offer evidence of the universe's earliest stars
SUMMARY: First-generation stars had short lives that ended in partial explosions and can be detected only through the chemical signatures they left in the stars that succeeded them

TITLE: Rescue operation faces extreme environment in search for missing sub
SUMMARY: The Coast Guard is working with the Navy and Canadian partners in the search, and some civilian research vessels are also rushing to the site to volunteer

TITLE: U.S. approves chicken made from cultivated cells, the nation's first 'lab-grown' meat
SUMMARY: The Agriculture Department gave the green light to Upside Foods and Good Meat, which had been racing to be the first in the U.S. to sell meat that doesn’t come from slaughtered animals

TITLE: Ocean heat wave that can cause extreme weather may linger into fall
SUMMARY: An experimental forecast produced by NOAA scientists found that the warm temperatures could remain elevated

TITLE: Harvard human remains case highlights need for body donation regulations, experts say
SUMMARY: Unlike with organ donation, few rules govern university programs or businesses that sell donated bodies, experts said

TITLE: Blistering heat grips the South and puts Texas under triple-digit temperatures
SUMMARY: Warnings and advisories for excessive heat are also in place across the Southwest and parts of New Mexico, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Florida

TITLE: Human remains and debris from sub returned to land after fatal implosion near Titanic site
SUMMARY: The Titan, a submersible operated by OceanGate Expeditions, lost contact with its home ship on June 18 off Newfoundland. All five people on board were killed

TITLE: Astronauts' urine and sweat are almost entirely recycled into drinking water with new system
SUMMARY: The end result, says NASA, is that the crew is drinking water that is even cleaner than Earth’s

TITLE: A disjointed jet stream has some climate scientists spooked
SUMMARY: Some researchers think climate change is disrupting the jet stream's flow and causing it to bake regions in heat longer

TITLE: Scientists have finally ‘heard’ the chorus of gravitational waves that ripple through the universe
SUMMARY: Albert Einstein predicted that when really heavy objects move through space-time — the fabric of our universe — they create ripples that spread through that fabric

TITLE: Record nighttime heat in Texas poses a sneaky risk to people's health
SUMMARY: Heat at night disrupts sleep and prevents the body from recovering and cooling down, making minimum temperatures a critical indicator of a heat wave’s severity, experts said

TITLE: Sea lions aren't acting like themselves — they're more aggressive because of algae bloom in California
SUMMARY: Warning signs were placed at Orange County beaches after two reports this week of sea lion-related injuries

TITLE: Forecast shows a wild weekend of storms as ongoing heat dome expands

SUMMARY: Overlapping and unrelenting heat waves are hitting the South and parts of the West

SUMMARY: Last week, global average temperatures set records or tied existing ones for four days in a row

SUMMARY: A projection indicated the northern lights could be visible this week in more than a dozen states. It was updated Monday evening to show only modest auroral activity

SUMMARY: Detected in February, this particular black hole is active and actually puny as they go — equivalent to about 9 million times the mass of our sun

TITLE: Giant sloth pendants suggest people arrived in the Americas thousands of years earlier than thought
SUMMARY: The ornaments made from giant sloths found in Brazil may be 25,000 to 27,000 years old, several thousand years before earlier theories say the first people arrived in the Americas

TITLE: Triple-digit temperatures persist across Southwest as heat dome expands
SUMMARY: Dangerously hot conditions across the Southwest are expected to stretch into next week

SUMMARY: “We’re packed,” said the Rev. Katie Sexton-Wood, the executive director of the Arizona Faith Network, which organizes and operates 11 “heat-relief centers” in Maricopa County

SUMMARY: Huy Fong Sriracha, which used to go for under $5 or $10 a bottle, is now selling for shocking amounts in some listings posted to sites with vast third-party marketplaces

SUMMARY: In its forecast posted Friday morning, the National Weather Service warned that a “searing heat wave is set to engulf much of the West Coast, the Great Basin, and the Southwest

SUMMARY: The findings comes from a consortium of climate scientists who study extreme weather and publish rapid findings about climate change’s role in major events

SUMMARY: A buoy near Manatee Bay recorded an astounding 101.1-degree water temperature Monday, a temperature common for hot tubs

SUMMARY: Three former military officials testified during the congressional hearing held by the House Oversight subcommittee on National Security, the Border, and Foreign Affairs

SUMMARY: About the length of a paperclip but skinny as pencil lead, it is translucent and sinuous like a jellyfish tentacle

SUMMARY: At least 42% of 1,500 doctors surveyed had never heard of alpha-gal syndrome, a tick-borne illness that can cause potentially life-threatening allergy to red meat

SUMMARY: Nuclear power now makes up about 25% of the generation of Georgia Power, the largest unit of Atlanta-based Southern Co

SUMMARY: The arguments illustrate scientists’ uncertainty about the next phases of climate change and just how to characterize the risk of extreme — hopefully unlikely — events as real-world climate disasters are  taking place

TITLE: NASA listens for Voyager 2 spacecraft after wrong command cuts contact
SUMMARY: Hurtling ever deeper into interstellar space, Voyager 2 has been out of touch ever since flight controllers accidentally sent a wrong command more than a week ago that tilted its antenna away from Earth

SUMMARY: The new research by Climate Central calculated the climate’s shift this July in comparison to a world unaffected by global warming

SUMMARY: Plans to address climate change rely on massively scaling up clean, solar electricity, but recycling solar panels can be a challenge

SUMMARY: Experts said the Perucetus colossus could have weighed as much as 375 tons

SUMMARY: Voyager 2 has been hurtling through space since its launch in 1977 to explore the outer solar system

TITLE: The most impressive meteor shower of the year will be visible this weekend
SUMMARY: The Perseid meteor shower is typically the most impressive of the year because it can produce the highest rate of shooting stars in the night sky

TITLE: What caused the Maui wildfires? How drought and wind played a part
SUMMARY: A distant hurricane and severe drought conditions combined to create the kind of disaster that some scientists say show how climate change is a "threat multiplier

SUMMARY: As the state braced for triple-digit temperatures, its energy grid has had a surplus of power with the help of renewable energy, battery storage capacity, and relatively lower demand

SUMMARY: The young activists argued Montana was violating their constitutional right to a clean and healthy environment by permitting fossil fuels without considering the climate

SUMMARY: From California floods to Maui fires, safety systems that were sometimes designed decades ago are getting overwhelmed by disasters on a scale that was previously hard to imagine

SUMMARY: Conservation measures and a wetter winter have improved the river’s health, leading to cuts' being dialed back

TITLE: Tropical Storm Hilary expected to deluge Southern California with heavy rain
SUMMARY: Conditions are favorable for Hilary to strengthen over the next two to three days

SUMMARY: The Indian Space Research Organization’s successful touchdown comes just days after a Russian spacecraft that was en route to the same area failed during an orbital maneuver and crashed into the lunar surface

SUMMARY: The 120-degree heat index smashed the previous record set in 1995 during the historic Chicago heat wave that killed more than 500 people

SUMMARY: Vivek Ramaswamy's claim that the climate agenda is a hoax was offset by China-focused ideas on reducing emissions, with some young conservative activists happy the topic was discussed at all

TITLE: FDA pet food investigation: What to know about diet-related heart disease in dogs
SUMMARY: At least 1,382 cases of heart damage, possibly diet-related, have been reported in dogs, although veterinary researchers believe the problem could be more widespread than the numbers suggest

TITLE: How Hurricane Idalia went from Category 1 to Category 4 overnight

SUMMARY: Warmer-than-usual water is a key ingredient in the formation and development of storms

SUMMARY: Strains of the Lyme bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi have a protective outer layer that appears to function as armor against the body's immune system, new research finds

TITLE: 'Just don't lick the taxidermy': Fighting over arsenic found at South Dakota's largest zoo
SUMMARY: Arsenic was found to be widespread in the taxidermy collection, creating a raging debate about whether the more than 150 animals should be destroyed

SUMMARY: A tablet-based tool can accurately identify the disorder in children ages 16 months to 30 months by following eye movements as the toddlers watch a video

SUMMARY: More than 50 million people are under heat alerts from Texas and Oklahoma north to Minnesota and Michigan and in mid-Atlantic states, such as Virginia and Maryland, through the Northeast

SUMMARY: A team of experts visited the cave to inspect an ancient Hebrew inscription but stumbled across a remarkable set of Roman weapons

SUMMARY: In order for SpaceX to resume Starship launches at its facility in Texas, the company will need to “implement all corrective actions that impact public safety,” according to the FAA

SUMMARY: Russian cosmonaut Valeri Polyakov holds the world record of 437 days, set in the mid-1990s

SUMMARY: In its 33-page report, an independent team commissioned by NASA cautioned that the negative perception surrounding UFOs poses an obstacle to collecting data

SUMMARY: Researchers at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory first achieved successful nuclear fusion in December in a major breakthrough after decades of work

SUMMARY: A near-death experience can be life-changing and inspire feelings of gratitude

SUMMARY: Authorities said that there is no imminent danger and that people should not panic

SUMMARY: An astronaut’s tool bag that accidentally floated away during a routine spacewalk is the newest object for skywatchers to find in the night sky
